item.title: Train AI Models Offline on Your Own Machine
item.description:
Want to train AI models without relying on the cloud? In this video, I‚Äôll show you how to fine-tune open-source models like TinyLlama completely offline ‚Äî right on your own machine.
‚úÖ No internet required after setup ‚úÖ Full data privacy ‚úÖ Works with low-cost hardware ‚úÖ Perfect for secure or isolated environments
üöÄ What You'll Learn: 0/ Intro to TinyLlama 1/ Downloading the base model 2/ Preparing your training data 3/ Fine-tuning offline 4/ Merging and testing your model 5/ Generating GGUF file and running it with llama-cli
Whether you're a developer, researcher, or just curious about AI on the edge ‚Äî this is your path to independent AI training.
üñ•Ô∏è Code + scripts: https://github.com/hassanhabib/AI.Llama.Traing.Offline
üí¨ Questions? Drop them in the comments ‚Äî I respond!
#OfflineAI #TinyLlama #LocalAI #AIFinetuning #PrivateAI #AITraining
item.author: (Hassan Habib)

item.title: Hacker News now runs on top of Common Lisp - Lisp journey
item.description: Hacker News was written in the Arc lisp dialect, a dialect created by Paul Graham. Arc was implemented on top of Racket, but that has now changed. HN runs on top of SBCL since a few months.But why? For performance reasons. I recently noticed that Hacker News no longer uses paging for long threads. In the past, when a discussion grew large, we had to click “More” to load the next page of comments, and dang would occasionally post helpful tips to remind us about this feature.

item.title: Google Shared My Phone Number!
item.description: When people started calling my personal mobile number with questions about a voluntary organisation I'm involved with, I was confused: we weren't sharing that number. It turns out that Google had decided to take the number I used to verify my identity for Google Business some years prior and start putting it in Google Search results. WTF, Google?
item.author: (https://www.facebook.com/itsdanq)

item.title: Avoiding reflection in C# in way unsafer ways!
item.description: For good reasons, many folks don't want to use reflection. Since .NET 8, we have a better way of dealing with this in most of the cases (when known in advance). But we can go the opposite: Make it even unsafer for a tiny bit performance!
